text:
while youâ€™re reading this,
some girl is out there crying
because AI turned her into porn
and no one believes her.

1. Hyderabad, Telangana (Sep 2024)
A man died by suicide after loan recovery agents shared a morphed nude of his wife. The loan was repaid, but the image still circulated.

2. Andhra Pradesh (Dec 2024)
A fisherman took his life after similar abuse. â‚¹2,000 loan. Fake nude of his wife. Already repaid.

3. Delhi (Jan 2025)
A man blackmailed a student with AI-generated nudes. He posed as a woman online to gain her trust.

4. Hyderabad (Dec 2024)
A student was blackmailed with a deepfake created from her profile photo.

5. Chennai (July 2023)
A techie morphed photos of women from public places and sold them on Telegram.

ğŸš¨ What's happening?
- Morphed nudes
- Deepfake porn
- Stolen private moments
- Anonymous, fast, AI-enabled abuse

ğŸ§¨ Used to:
- Blackmail
- Shame
- Silence
- Push women out

Sometimes, it ends in death.

But no one talks.
- 'Too uncomfortable.'
- 'Her fault.'
- 'Just online.'

Deepfakes are already here.
To shame. To silence. To destroy.

And the worst part?
- Just an app.
- Just 3 photos.
- No skills. No remorse.

ğŸ“¢ If you're in tech, give a damn.
FIGHT BACK:
- Report: cybercrime.gov.in
- Tools: Reality Defender, Hive AI, Video Authenticator
- Support: Cyber Saathi, IFF, Red Dot Foundation

We need laws.
We need accountability.
We need empathy.

Until then, the question isnâ€™t 'Is it real?'
Itâ€™s 'How many more lives will AI ruin?'

'Agree or not, she's the reason, men don't want to get married'

A woman lost her husband in a terrorist attack.

But somehowâ€¦
Sheâ€™s the villain in your story?

People are calling her:
- 'The reason men donâ€™t want to marry.'
- 'Too calm to be a real widow.'
- 'Attention-seeking.'
- 'Made up, fake, scripted.'

Why is it always a womanâ€™s fault?

She mourns silently - sheâ€™s cold.
She cries publicly - sheâ€™s dramatic.
She speaks up - sheâ€™s seeking attention.
She stays silent - sheâ€™s hiding something.

A man dies - and people find a way to blame the woman he left behind.

As if grief has a script.
As if a womanâ€™s pain must look a certain way.
As if you can lose your life partner and still have to prove that youâ€™re broken enough for people to believe you.

What kind of society are we?

Instead of standing with her, weâ€™re trying to tear her down for being too 'calm' in her trauma.
Too 'normal' for their taste.
Too 'presentable' for a widow.

Maybe she wore makeup because her husband loved to see her happy.
Maybe she spoke to the media because she wanted his story heard.
Maybe she didnâ€™t cry on camera â€” but is dying every second inside.

Let her mourn the way she wants.
Let her grieve with dignity.
Let her speak. Or stay silent.
But stop this cruel judgment.

She lost everything.
And all people gave her in return - was suspicion.

We need to be better.
Not for her.
For humanity.

Letâ€™s be clear:
The problem is not Himanshi.
The problem is us -
our mindset, our conditioning, our need to punish women for existing with dignity.

You can call her anything you want.
But sheâ€™s the one who lost the love of her life.
And still stands tall.

And thatâ€™s what terrifies you.

Before you come at me and say sh*t like - This doesn't belong here and all.

Just want to clarify this - I use this platform to raise my voice against the wrong - I have been doing this for the last 3 years.

If you don't like it - block me.
I'll prefer using my voice to speak against the things that feel wrong to me rather than sitting here and impressing the people who I don't even know about.

ğŸ›‘ Be kind.

Because you never know what battle someone is silently fighting.

ğŸ’” Donâ€™t be the reason someone cries themselves to sleep.
ğŸ’” Donâ€™t be the reason someone skips dinner, overthinking a harsh word.
ğŸ’” Donâ€™t be the reason someone stops wearing their favorite dress because of one careless comment.
ğŸ’” Donâ€™t be the reason someone logs off and never logs back in.
ğŸ’” Donâ€™t be the reason someone feels invisible, even in a room full of people.
ğŸ’” Donâ€™t be the reason someone questions their worth after trying their best.
ğŸ’” Donâ€™t be the reason someone dreads waking up for work every day.
ğŸ’” Donâ€™t be the reason someone doubts their talent, their voice, or their existence.
ğŸ’” Donâ€™t be the reason someone starts to believe that theyâ€™ll never be enough.

Instead -

ğŸŒ¼ Be the reason someone feels safe to speak up.
ğŸŒ¼ Be the reason someone eats peacefully tonight.
ğŸŒ¼ Be the reason someone wears their favorite outfit with pride.
ğŸŒ¼ Be the reason someone smiles and actually means it.
ğŸŒ¼ Be the reason someone finds the strength to keep going.
ğŸŒ¼ Be the reason someone remembers that kindness still exists in this world.
ğŸŒ¼ Be the reason someone feels human again.

Kindness isnâ€™t weakness.
Itâ€™s strength.
Itâ€™s healing.
Itâ€™s resistance in a world thatâ€™s grown too sharp, too fast.

So please -

ğŸ’¬ Be kind in the comments.
ğŸ“§ Be kind in the emails.
ğŸ—£ï¸ Be kind in the feedback.
ğŸ™‡ Be kind in the silences.
ğŸ’– Be kind especially when no oneâ€™s watching.
âœ¨ Be kind even when youâ€™re having a bad day.

Because in the end,
No one ever forgets how you made them feel.

Not your title.
Not your deadlines.
Not your fancy words.
Just the feeling.

Choose kindness. Every time.

You wonâ€™t believe what happened when I taught a chaiwala SQL.
I gave him a free YouTube playlist.
He finished it in 15 days.

Then built a dashboard for his tea stall.
Now he tracks peak hours, top-selling items, and even tips.

He doesnâ€™t have a degree.
He has discipline.

Degrees help.
But curiosity? It changes lives.

Never underestimate the power of free resources - and the will to learn.
Never underestimate me, I can write good fictional stories.

Thanks!

HR: 'We want someone who can handle pressure.'
Bhai, job chahiye ya Squid Game jeetna hai?

JD padh ke toh lag raha hai ki:

Coding bhi karo
Designing bhi karo
Marketing bhi sambhalo
Sales bhi le aao
Aur haan, chai bhi tumhi bana lena

Salary?
'We offer industry standards.'
Industry kaunse planet ki bhai?

Experience required: 2 years
Budget: 15k/month
Location: Bangalore (WFH not allowed, but chai peena allowed)

Also...
'Weâ€™re like a family'
Nahi bhai, kaafi toxic joint family lag rahe ho.

Dear companies,
Candidates want growth.
Not gaslighting.
Jobs, not jugaad.
Salaries, not samjhauta.

likefunnysupport

stay positive.
'Good things take time.'
'Everything happens for a reason.'

Yes.

The reason is - companies want 25-year-olds with 30 years of experience and no salary expectations.

Iâ€™ve applied to jobs at 3 AM.
Wrote 500 custom cover letters.
Got ghosted more than on dating apps.
Even ChatGPT is tired of writing resumes for me.

But people on LinkedIn?
Theyâ€™ll say:
'Just keep manifesting.'
'Rejection is redirection.'

No, Priya.
Rejection is depression when you havenâ€™t paid rent in 2 months.

So if youâ€™re out there job huntingâ€”
Tired, angry, confused, and still holding on?

Youâ€™re not alone.

Youâ€™re not lazy.
Youâ€™re just stuck in a broken system romanticized with Canva quotes.

'Your salary is a joke as compared to what AI Engineers earn'

This is what @Aditya Kachave says in his ad!

First of all,
calling someone's hard-earned salary a joke just to sell a â‚¹9 course is not marketing,
itâ€™s pure disrespect.

People are working 12â€“14 hours a day,
handling loans, family responsibilities, mental health struggles -
and this guy thinks it's cool to shame them just to make a quick buck?

And honestly, if AI Engineers are earning so much,
why are you selling a â‚¹9 course instead of living in a Dubai penthouse?
Bro, even my tea costs â‚¹10 these days.

If AI is so magical,
use it to generate some self-respect first.

Letâ€™s use some basic AI (Aka Intelligence, Artificially):

If the knowledge is so powerful, why is it priced lower than a Vada Pav?

If â‚¹9 could make you a crorepati, Ambani wouldâ€™ve bought the course by now.

If he's already earning crores, why is he spending lakhs running YouTube ads? Charity?

Truth is simple:
The â‚¹9 course is just the bait.

Once you buy, youâ€™ll get bombarded with 'special offers,' 'mentorship programs,' and 'advanced paid courses.'

Basically, â‚¹9 is just your entry fee to the real circus.

The disrespect is next level:
Imagine mocking someone's struggles,
their self-worth,
their 10 years of career,
just to sell a glorified WhatsApp forward?

Moral:
Anyone who has to disrespect you first to sell you something
doesnâ€™t want to help you -
they want to profit off your insecurity.

Stay sharp.
Don't let anyone belittle your journey for their commission.

Army College of nursing website was hacked today few hours ago.

The hackers filled the page with hateful, communal messages - promoting violence, hatred, and division between Hindus and Muslims.

They used hashtags like hashtag#KillHindus and hashtag#RespectMuslims to spread extremely dangerous ideologies.

This is not just a cyberattack.
This is an attack on humanity, peace, and coexistence.

Let's all stand together!

Using a dead man's picture with his wife mourning besides him.

Speechless.

A good manager doesnâ€™t just manage your work. 
They protect your sanity.

They guide you, support you, and get the best out of you - without making you feel like trash.

But a bad manager? 
They make you question your worth every single day.

According to a *Gallup study*, 70% of the variance in team engagement is directly linked to the *manager*.

Another survey shows *65% of employees would take a new boss over a pay raise*.

People donâ€™t leave jobs. 
They leave toxic managers. 
And no amount of free coffee or flexible hours can fix that.

If you're a manager, ask yourself honestly: 
*Would *you* want to report to you?*

Thanks Qaim Abbas for being a wonderful one! The best one till now!

These last 2 months flew by!

Thanks for making me feel safe, helping me grow and make the work feel more meaningful!

There are some influencers who'll shamelessly post all day about Crosscoder, Hey poach all day and I even saw some of them posting yesterday and today.

I have been asked to promote many times, getting 4k-5k for posting a copy-pasted post, I do colab with teams that I find useful and can be great for people.

But

Have you noticed many of them being silent on what happened in Kashmir? Some of them posted about it but the majority haven't.

You know why?

Because speaking up doesnâ€™t pay.

Thereâ€™s no brand deal. No affiliate code. No likes from corporate recruiters. No 'collaboration opportunity.'

Just a simple truth: If it's not profitable, itâ€™s not worth talking about.

Influencing has become a business, not a responsibility. And when real issues happen - issues that affect people, that deserve voices they go quiet.

Because silence is safer.

Because this issue wonâ€™t get them engagement - it could cost them everything.

â€“ They might lose followers
â€“ Upset brands
â€“ Offend recruiters
â€“ Be labelled 'controversial'
â€“ Lose out on collabs and visibility

This post might not get me likes or money. But if even one person starts questioning the silence of people they follow, itâ€™s worth it.

And if the people with thousands of followers, with platforms, with reachâ€¦ choose not to speak - then what are they even influencing?

Being an influencer doesnâ€™t mean being brand-friendly.

It means having the guts to stand up, even when itâ€™s uncomfortable.

Even when it hurts your reach, followers. Even when it affects your paycheck.

Use your voice for more than brand deals.

Or stop calling yourself an influencer.

So the next time you see someone flexing their 'personal brand' and hashtag#InfluencerLife, ask them one question:

What do you stand for when no oneâ€™s watching?

Here's one person posting an offer letter that looks like it's made on the word with an affiliate link and I'll leave it up to you now, decide who you want to support!

She was on a ventilator.
She couldnâ€™t speak.
She couldnâ€™t move.
She couldnâ€™t even scream.

And thatâ€™s when he raped her.
Right there, in the ICU.
While two nurses stood and watched.
They did nothing.

This happened at one of Indiaâ€™s top hospitals â€“ Medanta, Gurugram.
A place where people go to save lives.
Not to lose their dignity.

This is not just a news headline.
This is a terrifying reality for women in India.
Where even in a hospital bed, with machines keeping you alive,
You are not safe.

We talk about women empowerment.
We celebrate Womenâ€™s Day.
But what about womenâ€™s safety?
What about basic human decency?

This is not just the failure of one person.
This is the failure of an entire system.

If two nurses can watch a woman being raped and do nothing -
then who's sicker: the rapist, or the system?

Speak up. Share. Shout.
Let her voice be heard.
Because if we stay silent today,
Tomorrow it could be someone we know.
Someone you love.
Someone too helpless to scream.

You donâ€™t need to be her to fight for her. You just need to be human.

If this doesnâ€™t shake your soul, check if you still have one.
